title-group.article-title: Multiscale Entropy Analysis of Electroencephalography During Sleep in Patients With Parkinson Disease

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Neurology and Sleep Center, Shuang Ho Hospital, Taipei Medical University, New Taipei, Taiwan
2Sleep Center, Taipei Medical University Hospital, Taipei, Taiwan
3Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, Taipei Medical University Hospital, Taipei, Taiwan
4Department of Neurology, Taipei Medical University, Taipei, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Chaur-Jong Hu, Department of Neurology and Sleep Center, Shuang Ho Hospital, Taipei Medical University, 291, Jhongjheng Road, Jhonghe District, New Taipei 235, Taiwan. Email: chaurjongh@tmu.edu.tw

abstract.p: Sleep disorders are frequently seen in patients with Parkinson disease (PD), including rapid eye movement (REM) behavior disorder and periodic limb movement disorder. However, knowledge about changes in non-REM sleep in patients with PD is limited. This study explored the characteristics of electroencephalography (EEG) during sleep in patients with PD and non-PD controls. We further conducted multiscale entropy (MSE) analysis to evaluate and compare the complexity of sleep EEG for the 2 groups. There were 9 patients with PD (Hoehn-Yahr stage 1 or 2) and 11 non-PD controls. All participants underwent standard whole-night polysomnography (PSG), which included 23 channels, 6 of which were for EEG. The raw data of the EEG were extracted and subjected to MSE analysis. Patients with PD had a longer sleep onset time and a higher spontaneous EEG arousal index. Sleep stage-specific increased MSE was observed in patients with PD during non-REM sleep. The difference was more marked and significant at higher time scale factors (TSFs). In conclusion, increased biosignal complexity, as revealed by MSE analysis, was found in patients with PD during non-REM sleep at high TSFs. This finding might reflect a compensatory mechanism for early defects in neuronal network control machinery in PD.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: PD is a common neurodegenerative disease. In Asian countries, an estimated 35.8 to 68.3 per 100,000 people have PD. 1 The characteristics of PD include rigidity, resting tremor, bradykinesia, and balance impairment. 2 The pathology and pathophysiology of PD indicate loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the midbrain, with subsequent global brain atrophy. 3 Many non-motor symptoms also occur in PD, such as sensory complaints, mood disorders, and excessive daytime sleepiness. 4 Sleep disorders are frequently seen in patients with PD, REM behavior disorder (RBD), and periodic limb movement (LM) disorder. 4 Both of them are thought to reflect dopaminergic insufficiency in the brain, and RBD could be a prodromal symptom of PD. 5 In patients with PD, the changes in non-REM sleep are currently not well understood.

PSG is the gold standard for studying sleep physiology in clinical and research settings. Data from PSG indicate that sleep consists of a REM or dream sleep stage and periods of non-REM sleep, namely sleep stages 1, 2, 3, and 4. Sleep stages 3 and 4 can be classified as deep sleep or slow wave sleep (SWS). 6 Prior PSG studies have documented that patients with PD display increased sleep latency and decreased total sleep time, SWS time, REM sleep time, and sleep efficiency, with the changes becoming more marked as the disease progresses. 7 PSG data are mainly analyzed by manual scoring, according to specific criteria, and thus provide a semiquantitative measurement. Detailed analysis of EEG data during sleep in patients with PD is still limited.

Entropy analysis, based on information theory, has been applied to describe the complexity of a system. 8 A healthy system should adequately adapt to a variety of changes; therefore, signals obtained from individuals who respond to the changing external and internal environment should contain complex behaviors and rich information. Recently, entropy, or complexity analysis, has been used to analyze biosignals, and has yielded novel insight beyond that provided by traditional methods. 9 –11 Because biological systems operate across time, MSE is developed to investigate the characteristics of complexity of a biosignal at different time scales. 12 The main idea of MSE is to reveal the complexity of a signal in different time scales via a series of coarse-grained procedures. The higher coarse-grained signal represents low-resolution observation of a system and removal of short time scale behavior. Because of its ability to provide multiple time scale information of a biological system, MSE analysis provides a useful tool to assist in classifying diseases and predicting prognoses. 13,14

We hypothesized that the entropy of the EEG portion of PSG, obtained at various sleep stages, would provide information about the pathophysiology underlying PD. Thus, this study explored the characteristics of EEG during sleep in patients with PD, as well as in non-PD controls. We conducted MSE analysis to evaluate the complexity of sleep EEG and to compare the results between the 2 groups.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Nine patients with PD rated at stage 1 or 2 according to the Hoehn-Yahr scale and 11 non-PD controls were recruited for this study. Patients with PD consisted of 4 men and 5 women, and the control group consisted of 7 men and 4 women (P = .39). Patients were older than the non-PD controls (mean age 78.2+7.4 and 61.2+7.2 years, respectively; P = .01). All participants gave their written informed consent, and the study protocol was approved by the institutional review board of Taipei Medical University Hospital, Taiwan. The mean age of the patients with PD was 78.2 ± 7.4 years, and of non-PD controls was 61.2 ± 7.2 years. All patients with PD were taking regular medication, including levodopa, anticholinergic agents, and dopamine agonists, and the controls were healthy volunteers, without regular medication.

sec.title: Polysomnography
sec.p: Standard all-night PSG was performed in the sleep laboratory. PSG was conducted under continuous monitoring by sleep technicians, using a computerized sleep-scoring system (Sandman; Tyco Ltd, Ottawa, Canada). PSG recording began at the participants’ usual bedtime and ended at their usual wake-up time in the morning. PSG included 23 channels as follows: 6 EEG channels (C3/C4/O1/O2/A1/A2 in EEG 10-20 systems), 2 channels for electrooculography, 6 channels for electromyography over the submental and bilateral anterior tibialis muscles, 2 channels for electrocardiography, 1 channel for a nasal cannula flow meter, 2 channels for abdominal and chest movement, 1 channel for pulse oximetry, 1 channel for a position sensor, 1 channel for microphone recording of snoring, and 1 channel for video recording. The impendence of each channel was kept at <5 kΩ. Total PSG recording time was at least 7 hours. PSG scoring across a 30-second epoch was performed manually, by a board-certificated, experienced sleep technician, according to Rechtschaffen and Kales criteria; the technician was blinded to participants’ classification. The parameters for sleep onset latency, sleep efficiency, total sleep time, REM latency, ratios for each sleep stage, and events such as those measured by the apnea–hypopnea index (AHI), LM index, and EEG arousal index were scored accordingly. The raw data from the PSG were stored digitally for further processing and analysis.

sec.title: Power Spectrum Analysis of EEG
sec.p: We selected 2 pairs of EEG electrodes (C3A2 and C4A1: central EEG tracings) for further analysis. The sampling frequency of raw EEG data was 128 Hz, and digital resolution was 12 bits. The EEG signals were filtered between 0.3 and 50 Hz. A notch filter of 50 Hz was also applied. The raw EEG data were mainly processed using MATLAB software (MATLAB, R2007a; MathWorks, Natick, Massachusetts) for advanced computation. The epochs at which any sleep event (such as apnea–hypopnea or LMs) had occurred were excluded from analysis to prevent interference. Fast Fournier Transform of EEG was computed for each 30-second epoch. Power spectrum was obtained by calculating the square of FFT of the signals. The numbers of included epochs of patients with PD and controls were 486.6 ± 129.0 and 472.6 ± 79.1, respectively, for further analysis. The absolute and relative power of 4 frequency bands were calculated, δ (0.5-2 Hz), θ (2-8 Hz), α (8-12 Hz), and β(12-20 Hz). The mean frequency of each epoch was computed based on weighted mean by power distribution. The detailed equation is given as

sec.title: Multiscale Entropy Analysis
sec.p: An MSE series was obtained from a sample entropy analysis of the signals for different time scale factors (TSFs). Computation of the signals at different TSFs was performed through a coarse-grain procedure of the original data. The coarse-grain procedure divided the original signals into nonoverlapping windows of equal length, corresponding to the TSFs. The average X of signals for each window was calculated, and a new time series was obtained. Sample entropy was then calculated for each time series in different scale factors. We utilized PhysioNet software to calculate the MSE of EEG signals. 15
Given a time series denoting measured EEG
The coarse-grain series was obtained by averaging the variables in nonoverlapping windows by TSFs and then calculating X as follows:
MSE for each TSF was computed according to the following equation:
MSE(s) = SpEn(X(s),m,r) (4)

where SpEn denotes sample entropy, m denotes the vector of length, and r denotes the tolerance of similarity. In the current study, we selected values of m = 2 and r = 0.15 for MSE computation. Figure 1 demonstrated an example of power spectra and MSE analysis of sleep EEG in a patient with PD.

caption.p: An example of sleep electroencephalography (EEG), power spectrum density, and multiple-scale entropy in a patient with Parkinsons disease. A, Three traces of EEG (C3-A2) were shown. Typical K complex and sleep spindle can be noted in raw sleep EEG, the first trace representing stage 2 sleep. Coarse-grained raw signal by averaging 10 and 20 consecutive samples representing time scales 10 and 20, respectively, were shown as the second and third traces. Worth noting, the higher time scale produces more coarse-grained effect where the signals become smooth. B, The power spectrum density was calculated by computing the square of Fast Fournier Transform of the raw signal. C, The multiscale entropy (MSE) of sleep EEG was shown. Two arrows indicate the sample entropy corresponding to 2 time scales as 10 and 20.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Statistical analyses were processed using SPSS software (SPSS Inc, v15.0, Chicago, Illinois). The results for continuous variables are presented as mean and standard deviation. The Mann-Whitney U test was used to compare the basic continuous variables between the patient group with PD and the control group, namely sleep power spectrum analysis and MSE parameters. Furthermore, we computed the Pearson correlation between age and MSE parameters in 2 groups to investigate the association between age and MSE. The significance level was set at P < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Table 1 presents the comparisons between the 9 participants in the PD patient group and 11 participants in the control group for sleep characteristics from PSG. There were no significant differences between the groups for total sleep time, time in bed, sleep efficiency, REM latency, awakenings, and ratio of sleep stages. Patients with PD showed significantly longer sleep onset time than controls (20.20 ± 13.98 vs 9.60 ± 8.03 minutes; P = .03). Patients with PD obtained lower AHI values (9.47 ± 11.80/h vs 29.09 ± 20.93/h; P = .01) and total arousal index values (19.10 ± 12.40/h vs 30.48 ± 15.83/h; P = .05) than the controls. Patients with PD also showed higher spontaneous EEG arousal index scores than controls (8.67 ± 3.81/h vs 4.06 ± 4.21/h; P = .03).

caption.p: Comparison of Parameters from Polysomnography Between Patients With Parkinson Disease and Controls.

fn.p: Abbreviations: EEG, electroencephalography; LM, limb movement; REM, rapid eye movement; SD, standard deviation; SWS, slow wave sleep.

sec.p: Absolute and relative spectral powers of the two groups were calculated. We found no substantial differences between groups for any sleep stage, except in a few EEG frequency bands such as β power in sleep stage 1, θ power in sleep stage, SWS and REM at C3, θ power in stage awake, stage 1, REM at C4 by absolute power spectral analysis, and β power in sleep stage REM at C3, θ power in stage awake at C4 by relative power spectral analysis. We also found no differences in mean frequency of EEG at the various sleep stages. In the Pearson correlation analysis, no significant correlations were found between age and MSE parameters in all sleep stages for both groups.

Figure 2 shows a comparison of the MSE analysis of EEG signals for the 2 groups. For data obtained while the participants were awake, only 1 significant difference was observed (s = 7 for C3A2, s: time scale) when the TSFs were analyzed individually. However, for greater TSFs (s = 5-20 for C3A2; s = 6-20 for C4A1) a significant increase in MSE was noted in patients with PD during sleep stage 2 compared to controls. Finally, during REM sleep the only difference in MSE between the 2 groups pertained to a single TSF (s = 2 for C4A1).

caption.p: Multi-scale entropy (MSE) analysis of electroencephalography (EEG) according sleep stage of patients with Parkinson disease and control. The asterisk represents significant difference of MSE at certain time scale factor (*P < .05, **P < .01). Note the significant higher MSE at higher time scale factors in the patients with Parkinson disease during sleep stage 2 and slow wave sleep compared to controls.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We examined EEG data from PSG (PSG-EEG) for the awake state and different sleep stages. MSE quantifies the degree of complexity over a range of time scales. No significant differences emerged between the 2 groups for changes in MSE analysis of PSG-EEG during either the awake state or REM. However, we did observe significant differences between the 2 groups for EEG signal complexity during non-REM sleep, including sleep stages 1, 2, and slow-wave sleep. Furthermore, the between-group differences identified by MSE were more distinct and characteristic than those calculated by traditional power spectral analysis. This finding suggests the possibility that in patients with PD, early changes in the sleep EEG may display a degree of nonlinearity which traditional analysis tools may not be able to detect. We propose that MSE analysis could be a useful and robust tool to identify underlying pathophysiological changes during the sleep of patients with PD. To our knowledge, this was the first study to investigate MSE analysis of the biosignal complexity of PSG-EEG in patients with PD. Although further research is needed, MSE analysis may provide a potentially useful tool to PD researchers.

The pathomechanism underlying the changes of MSE in PD is still uncertain. Previous studies have reported altered complexity of MSE for EEG signals in patients with Alzheimer disease (AD). 16 An increasing complexity, correlated with cognitive decline, has also been documented in patients with severe AD. 17 The present study found that MSE, at a TSF of 1, was equal to the sample entropy of the original EEG and did not differ between patients with PD and controls. This suggests that the complexity of EEG may not be affected at low TSFs but differences were more notable at higher TSFs. The neurophysiologic mechanism responsible for the difference in complexity across TSFs remains unclear. However, MSE at high TSF could possibly show the difference of interconnection of the cortical functional islands. 18 Previous studies in patients with AD found variable results in increased or decreased complexity. 19 –21 This diversity of results across frequencies and TSFs, emphasizes the importance of examining a range of time scales when exploring EEG signal dynamics. Given that EEG assesses the effect of the degree of connectivity within neuronal populations, and measures complexity using synthetic neuronal models, EEG signal complexity could be altered by neuronal connectivity. 22,23 The MSE observed at different TSFs may reflect the hierarchical composition of the central nervous system from cerebral cortex level to cell column, layer, and neuronal cellular level. The complexity at different time scales might also represent specific pathophysiological mechanisms associated with PD, as in AD. As the disease progresses, the complexity might change in different Hoehn-Yahr stages. Our findings probably reflect a compensatory mechanism for early defects in the neuronal network control machinery due to PD. However, this is still a premature hypothesis. Further research is warranted to elucidate the association between basic pathophysiology and the MSE patterns at a more detailed level such as cellular, molecular, or pathway.

Notably, we found the changes in MSE patterns for EEG during sleep may be stage specific in patients with PD. The major differences in complexity were observed during non-REM sleep. Sleep is a highly regulated behavior involving complex neural networks and neurotransmitters. Participants were mainly in the early stage of PD (Hoehn and Yahr scale score between 1 and 2). Although the mechanism is unknown, our data support the hypothesis that during early PD, the complexity of EEG may be affected initially during non-REM sleep. Sleep disturbances commonly occur in patients with PD at some point during their disease, and often negatively affect the patient’s quality of life. Changes in complexity can be noted during sleep rather than awake EEG. These findings are compatible with clinical observations that, for patients with PD, sleep disorders may be the initial presentations of the disease and may even occur years before Parkinsonism manifests.

There are limitations in this study. First, the relatively small number of cases may result in inadequate statistical power. Second, we recruited only patients with early PD instead of the whole spectrum of the disease. Third, we did not ensure a washout of patients’ medication before the PSG study. Anti-PD medication might influence the results and interpretation, but discontinuing the medication was neither practical nor ethical. Fourth, the 2 participant groups differed significantly in age. Studies regarding the effect of age on MSE in EEG during sleep remain lacking. Although our correlational analysis of the age and MSE parameters revealed no significant association, further clarification of this point is needed. Fifth, AHI in the non-PD group is higher than PD group. This finding is consistent with a previous observation that patients with PD may display a higher airway tone and lower frequency of sleep breathing disorder. 24 We thus excluded epochs containing apnea and hypopnea events from our PSG-EEG MSE analysis to minimize this interference. Sixth, the sample frequency of EEG in our study was set at 128 Hz, which may cause undersampling and alter the results of the MSE analysis. Further study is suggested to determine optimal sample frequency for MSE results. Finally, we used data only from selected central electrodes (C3/C4) corresponding to the sensorimotor area for analysis. Potential site-specific changes in EEG signals may occur in patients with PD, and more comprehensive montages for EEG analysis should be considered in future studies.

In summary, we found that patients in early PD displayed increased MSE in their EEG during non-REM sleep, at relatively high TSFs. The MSE approach combined by a wide range of time scale analysis of EEG may be regarded as a powerful complementary tool for assessing the characteristics of patients with PD. Studies using larger patient samples, and follow-up over a longer period, are warranted.

fn.p: Full-color figures are available online at http://eeg.sagepub.com
